text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Parliament ratified the Geneva convention on refugees. The convention will come into force 90 days after the delivery of the deposit letters to the United Nations.
- Prime Minister Tiit Vaehi starts a three-day visit to Ukraine.
- The government yesterday delivered presents and bonuses to junior disabled sportsmen.

- Estonia intends to continue with a positive approach to relations with Russia and hopes that political rhetoric would lessen to give way to a more constructive mood, the Estonian foreign ministry says in a statement.

- Four servicemen of the Defence Forces Guard Battalion received last week slight wounds in a shooting incident, resulting from the carelessness of their squad leader who was demonstrating an automatic gun.
- Estonia hopes that visa-free travel with Finland may come into force from May 1.

- The prosecutor's office has ended a case against 92-year old Idel Jakobson for crimes against humanity in 1941-1949, involving 1,183 people, as Jakobson's mental and physical condition would not enable him to stand trial.
- Urmas Kaju, counsellor to the Bank of Estonia who signed an agreement on a doubtful $10 million deal, was yesterday excluded from the council of the central bank.

- President Lennart Meri has announced the names of 190 people who are to receive the orders of merit on February 24. Among them are the former German and Danish foreign ministers, a 12- year old Estonian boy who at the time of the tragic road accident at Pala cut off the electric system in the school-bus to avoid an explosion.

- The Privatisation Agency Council rejected the request of the Estonian Shipping Company to sign an agreement for a 30 million kroon loan from Union Bank, intended to promote the shipping operator project Hansatee.
